thread.title: First picture of police officer who suffered "life-changing injuries" as terrorist ploughed into pedestrians on Westminster Bridge
thread.title_full: First picture of police officer who suffered "life-changing injuries" as terrorist ploughed into pedestrians on Westminster Bridge

author: Chris kitching
title: First picture of police officer who suffered "life-changing injuries" as terrorist ploughed into pedestrians on Westminster Bridge
text:
Police name fifth person to die after London terror attack Share this video Watch Next 
His sister Nikki Tapner, 42, told the Sun : “I don’t know that much about what’s going on. Read More Memorial fund for family of murdered PC Keith Palmer surpasses £500,000 in 24 hours 
“All I have been told is he has been hurt but his life is not in danger. My parents are there with him.” 
A former colleague said PC Aves suffered "life-changing" injuries and the car "came out of nowhere" as it hit the tro. 
PC Smith was said to have undergone operations in hospital after suffering leg injuries, while PC Bryant was also injured but has been released from hospital. 
The Lambeth-based officers had just attended a commendation ceremony at the new Met Police headquarters in Cannon Row when the attack unfolded. Police set up a cordon on the bridge (Photo: REUTERS) 
Several pedestrians were hit as Masood, born in Britain as Adrian Russell Ajao, drove the car onto the pavement and then crashed before fatally stabbing PC Palmer. Read More Terrorist Khalid Masood 'looked at WhatsApp on his phone moments before ploughing into pedestrians and stabbing police officer' 
The terrorist was then shot dead inside the gates at the Houses of Parliament. 
PC Palmer, 48, London college worker and mum-of-two Aysha Frade, 43, US tourist Kurt Cochran, 54, and London pensioner Leslie Rhodes, 75, were killed in Wednesday's attack, and at least 50 were injured. 
On Friday morning Acting Deputy Commissioner Mark Rowley said two officers who were injured on Westminster Bridge remain in hospital after suffering "significant injuries". 
Mr Rowley told reporters that 31 people were hospitalised following the attack. A police officer rearranges a floral tribute to the victims (Photo: PA) Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
